text:
You'd think with a complicated game like Monster Hunter, watching a beginner like Gura would make me cringe, but it actually reminds me of when I started with my own first Monster Hunter game which was Monster Hunter Tri for the Wii. I was using the Great Sword and not even using the super powerful charge attack at all, I was just swinging it all around trying to make combos. Even played online that way and nobody ever stopped to tell me: "You know, maybe you should try a different weapon if you wanna play that way..."
Good times. I'm happy with my skill level now, of course, but I still had fun back then and it's all that matters.
(Although I do apologize to everyone I might have played with back then and felt too awkward to say anything)

text:
Chargeblade is harder to master, but u can do it! Its gonna be rewarding and its hella strong!

Would suggest a online video for good results, you know about sword mode charging axe mode and discharging some explosion, but it can go further. Charge the shield also, to create an even stronger axe, more dmg and allow you to use the ultimate move, condensed discharge, which will empty all the jars over using just one jar w each blast. 

As you strike w sword mode and charge it, you will get a  "hot" sword, which will bounce and deal less damage regardless of sharpness. This means it has too much power and needs to go to the axe. 

Try to stay nearer the monster, dodge to the side or try to roll under a monster if you are very close. The monster is usually open right after a move and can be safely hit for a short while. ( some monster will combo, need to understand the moves).

text:
Dude Gura, I know I've said this before, but more than ever, I am SO EXCITED that you're having fun with this game. I know it was rough before the stream and early on (Monster Hunter is honestly always awful at the beginning) but watching you have fun fighting monsters and squealing at all the cute things really really made my day. I know all the controls and all the weapon combos and whatnot are incredibly complicated to learn, but once you get used to everything you get to be SO COOL. And I believe in your ability to learn whatever weapon you wanna play, sharky; take some time to try them out on your own, maybe ask Ina-sensei for some tips, and I know you'll be a hunting MASTER before long!

I really hope you keep hunting and having fun with it Gura! It'll be really cool to see you and Ina play together, maybe with some of your senpai too. The dream, though, would be a chance for the Shrimps to hunt with you someday; I know it might be unlikely, but I've heard Luna-senpai has done it before, and it would actually be the highlight of all the (way too many) hours I've spent playing Monster Hunter. I can dream, and you can't stop me!

Thanks for the stream, little shark. It was a fun week, even if the Avatar watchalong was criiiiinge. I hope you're able to get some good rest, and I'll see you next week. <3

text:
I always felt like bow was most complicated, assuming you're using all the abilities and not just spamming something for a speedrun.

Charge blade feels like a simple conveyer belt system. Charge energy and send it down the line until everything's full and then unleash the saed.

Bow has a wild assortment of things to juggle at any moment. Coatings, close range dps, long range moves, KO shot. Is there time for a dragon piercer? All while managing stamina, distance, and charge level.

Learning charge blade was downright relaxing after that...
author: @SubjectiveObserver

text:
¬†@pizhhhout¬† It is, especially if you use all of its kit (in both forms). It can be very overwhleming and hard to handle for all new CB users or non-CB users. The sheer amount of mechanics in both forms make it the most complicated weapon in MH.

Like every other weapons, once the user has mastered it, it becomes a part of the user and all the moves will flow beautifully and flawlessly.
author: @MenrvaS

text: ¬†@MenrvaS¬† CB has a very straightforward upkeep. It's not like IG with all it's different buffs and changing moveset depending on which buffs you have or don't have on, or pre-Rise Hunting Horn where optimal play requires you to constantly playing songs.
author: @pizhhhout

text: ¬†@SubjectiveObserver¬† CB is the Most complicated on a technical Level. Although now that different shottypes are back an argument can be made. But in the Core Bow still has only 2 attacks with a charge mechanic.  Let‚Äòs put it that way. Bow is hard to learn while CB is hard to understand. In the end it‚Äòs subjective anyway.

author: @fabianschultz

text: ¬†@Yog-Sothoth620¬† A new comer to monster hunter isn't going to know about guard points, plus they probably don't know that you can charge the shield and blade. Guard points require pin point time for it to be the most efficient weapon. That's why it's considered the most complicated. Not by use but by the tec the game doesn't tell you.
author: @tommygunab148

text:
¬†@pizhhhout¬†  As far as my EXP with IG goes, keeping up the red buff is more than enough to use more damaging movesets, which are mapped to the same buttons as the non-red ones so you dont have to memorize and you should be using the red movesets. Other two buffs are for general purposes and you have to get all 3 for large performance boosts.  Kinsect management is upto what you are using and why you are using it, it can be complicated.

HH optimal play is not constantly playing songs but constantly hitting the head for fatigue, if no hammer user is present, while playing multiple songs. HH is definitely not complicated but it is not easy to play. Just constantly playing song is how a normal or a new HH user uses it, and it is what seperates the best HH users from the rest.

CB is the most complicated because of its main mechanic that can free flow each move after one another and giving the user various options to choose from. Some of the moves also have additional offensive or defensive effects. Its basically a fighting game moveset in weapon form.

Well, if people use it purely for AED or SAED, it is pretty much a GS with extra steps, but that is not entirely true either.
author: @MenrvaS

text: ¬†@WatamelonGod¬† Heya fellow CB main. And no it's not that complicated even compared to other weapons.
author: @Helpfulhelp

text:
¬†@Helpfulhelp¬† 
The general vibe this comment thread is giving off is that complicated =/= difficult to learn. The main thing that makes charge blade so complicated is how versatile it's moveset is and how freely it flows between actions. So many possible moves to perform at any given time, not to mention certain "hidden mechanics" like guard points. Even as a newcommer in 4U, I could tell that the basics were charge up phials and release them in axe form. But I didn't learn about charging the shield and guard points until way after in world. That was mostly because I didn't main CB so I didn't go looking for this info, but my point still stands.

LS is super easy in rise because its counter window is far more generous than before especially with its changes, like not losing a spirit level when missing a spirit slash or helm splitter being way faster than World's. 
I know cuz I main CB and LS lmao
author: @WatamelonGod

text: ¬†@KikonSketches¬† Yea, I sat down today dedicated to learn it and finally got the hang of it. Did have to watch a video guide since the game doesn't freaking tell you how to charge the shield and only alludes to the fact you can charge the sword. Not sure what the hell they were thinking when making those in-game manuals...Dunno if my may of using it is optimal but it sure feels effective. Still loving IG and HH tho. Definitely gonna be swapping between the three.
author: @tyraster8603

text: ¬†@tyraster8603¬† yeah I have no idea why they decided not to mention it at all or show how to do it, but its worth it, such a fun weapon, best way to enjoy the game is swapping weapons is how I feel :)
author: @KikonSketches

text: I feel like the ranged weapons are better for beginners. I used to use a great sword in world and it was a harsh experience learning it. I'm using the heavy bowgun in rise and it's been a way more fun experience.
author: @0boro

text: ¬†@0boro¬† well great sword (in my opinion) isn't a beginner weapon, its heavy and slow and requires patience and often a good knowledge of the habits of monsters to land devastating hits, personally I feel the easiest to learn for a beginner is the hammer, very straight forward and not much to it.
author: @KikonSketches

text:
¬†@0boro¬† HBG and LBG can be good weapons for both new and veteran hunters. New players can use them to deal dmg from a safe distance and learn about the monsters (if they pay attention) while veteran hunters can also use it for support purposes like ailments, cutting tails, breaking parts. 

Great Sword is an easy to learn and straightforward weapon, but it is definitely not a beginner weapon. Good thing is, using GS forces you to learn about the monsters and their patterns to the point that you can already tell their hitboxes by only looking at their body langauge. 

I once had a similiar harsh experience back in FU/2G days (Gen 2 MH) with Khezu using GS with barely any solo experience and steel armor (weak to lightning) which forced me to not getting hit. It was hard and frustrating, but it was worth it.

If someone ask me how to be better at MH, i would recommend GS. You may not use GS after that, but you will definitely use its knowledge.
author: @MenrvaS

text:
¬†@0boro¬† I think people downplay how difficult it is to play the great sword because of how straightforward the weapon is but due to how slow it is and the charging mechanic, you really need to choose your shots so you need to really know the monsters' attack patterns whereas with most other weapons, you can just kinda wing it. I think it's one of the worst beginner weapons for sure.

I haven't tried ranged weapons yet but I have to say that Hunting Horn is a very beginner friendly weapon and so is the Insect Glaive and they are both very fun to play.
